Director Procurement-APAC @ McCormick I Team Lead 3PP - (RUMEAA & NEA) | Global Procurement - Directs @ Beiersdorf | Procurement | Supply Chain | Operations | NPD | Lean Manufacturing | Regulatory Compliance
Comment:
Absolutely, Rishabh! Your analysis captures the nuanced implications of the U.S. tariff hike brilliantly. As the global landscape shifts, we must indeed view these challenges as opportunities for strategic repositioning.
Leveraging India’s strengths in manufacturing and technology is crucial, and your call for enhanced economic diplomacy resonates profoundly. If we can align our policies with future trends, we stand to not only mitigate the immediate impacts but also emerge as a leading player in global supply chains.
As we navigate these turbulent waters, fostering an adaptable mindset among our leaders will be key. It’s imperative that we embrace a long-term vision, incorporating macro-awareness into our strategies and decision-making processes.
Looking forward to seeing how India can seize this moment to redefine its role on the world stage!

Comment:
India has spent decades playing catch-up in global trade without ever truly owning its narrative. We talk about becoming a $5 trillion economy, but I don’t see enough leadership willing to take bold bets.

Headline: CFO, Chartered Accountant-2001, Ex-Ed (IIM-A), FMCG, Media, Healthcare
Comment:
I think that the end game is to make each country review and adjust its tariffs and trade deficit (in that order). US has been able to get almost everyone (relatively small) to the table but not China (yet) for which this entire drama is being done.

Water will find it’s level over the next few weeks. 

India is accommodating and willing to work with the US. Thats a positive. We are primarily a domestic consumption economy and that’s another big positive.
